short_description: The ultimate American comfort food - creamy, cheesy pasta baked until golden and bubbling. This Southern-style version uses a blend of cheeses for the richest, most indulgent result.
steps: Cook macaroni until just al dente, drain.
Melt butter in a large pot, whisk in flour.
Cook roux for 2 minutes until golden.
Gradually whisk in milk and cream until smooth.
Simmer until thickened, about 5 minutes.
Remove from heat, stir in most of the cheese until melted.
Beat eggs, temper with some hot sauce, then stir into pot.
Add mustard, cayenne, salt, and pepper.
Fold in cooked macaroni.
Pour into buttered baking dish.
Top with remaining cheese.
Bake at 180°C (350°F) for 30 minutes until bubbly and golden.
cooking_tips: Use a mix of cheese for depth of flavor.
The eggs make the texture extra creamy.
Let rest 5 minutes before serving for best texture.
nutrition_benefits: High in calcium and protein from cheese. Provides energy from carbohydrates. An indulgent treat best enjoyed in moderation.

short_description: Fall-off-the-bone tender pork ribs slathered in tangy-sweet BBQ sauce. This American BBQ classic features a spice rub and slow cooking for maximum flavor and tenderness.
steps: Remove membrane from back of ribs.
Mix brown sugar with all dry spices for the rub.
Coat ribs generously with the spice rub.
Let sit at room temperature for 30 minutes.
Wrap ribs tightly in foil with a splash of vinegar.
Bake at 150°C (300°F) for 2.5 hours.
Unwrap ribs and increase oven to 200°C (400°F).
Brush generously with BBQ sauce.
Bake uncovered for 20-30 minutes, basting twice.
Let rest 10 minutes before cutting.
Serve with extra sauce on the side.
cooking_tips: Removing the membrane is essential for tenderness.
Low and slow is the key to fall-off-the-bone ribs.
Make your own BBQ sauce for best results.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein and B vitamins from pork. The slow cooking makes the meat easy to digest. A celebratory meal for special occasions.

short_description: A rich, creamy soup from New England featuring tender clams, diced potatoes, and smoky bacon in a velvety broth. This iconic regional dish warms hearts on cold coastal days.
steps: Steam clams until opened, reserve liquid. Chop clam meat.
Dice bacon and fry until crispy, set aside.
In bacon fat, sauté onion and celery until soft.
Add butter, then flour to make a roux.
Gradually add clam liquid (strained) and water.
Add diced potatoes, bay leaves, and thyme.
Simmer until potatoes are tender.
Stir in cream and chopped clams.
Heat through but don't boil.
Season with salt and white pepper.
Serve in bread bowls with crispy bacon on top.
cooking_tips: Use fresh clams for the best flavor.
White pepper is traditional - it doesn't show in the cream.
Bread bowls make it extra special.
nutrition_benefits: Clams are rich in iron, B12, and zinc. The cream provides calcium. A hearty, satisfying meal perfect for cold weather.

short_description: Quintessential American breakfast pancakes that are impossibly fluffy and light. The buttermilk creates a tender crumb while adding a subtle tang that pairs perfectly with maple syrup.
steps: Mix flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.
In another bowl, whisk buttermilk, eggs, melted butter, and vanilla.
Pour wet ingredients into dry and mix until just combined.
Don't overmix - lumps are okay!
Let batter rest 5 minutes.
Heat a griddle or pan over medium heat.
Lightly butter the cooking surface.
Pour ¼ cup batter per pancake.
Cook until bubbles form and edges set.
Flip and cook until golden.
Serve stacked with butter and warm maple syrup.
cooking_tips: Lumpy batter makes the fluffiest pancakes.
Wait for bubbles before flipping.
Keep cooked pancakes warm in a low oven.
nutrition_benefits: A hearty breakfast providing energy for the day. Eggs add protein. Pair with fruit for added nutrition.

short_description: The iconic American dessert - a buttery, flaky crust filled with cinnamon-spiced apples. Nothing says home quite like a warm slice of apple pie, especially with a scoop of vanilla ice cream.
steps: Make crust: pulse flour, salt, and cold butter until pea-sized.
Add ice water and form into two disks. Chill 1 hour.
Peel, core, and slice apples thinly.
Toss apples with sugar, spices, lemon juice, and cornstarch.
Roll one disk and fit into 9-inch pie dish.
Add apple filling, mounding in center.
Roll second disk for top crust. Cut vents.
Place over filling, crimp edges decoratively.
Brush with beaten egg.
Bake at 220°C (425°F) for 15 minutes.
Reduce to 180°C (350°F) and bake 40 more minutes.
Cool before slicing. Serve with ice cream.
cooking_tips: Use a mix of sweet and tart apples.
Keep butter very cold for flaky crust.
Shield edges with foil if browning too fast.
nutrition_benefits: Apples provide fiber and vitamin C. The spices have anti-inflammatory properties. A beloved treat for celebrations.

short_description: Crispy, golden-brown fried chicken with a perfectly seasoned crust and juicy interior. This Southern classic is the ultimate comfort food, featuring a buttermilk marinade and secret spice blend.
steps: Soak chicken in buttermilk for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.
Mix flour with all spices and seasonings.
Remove chicken from buttermilk, let excess drip off.
Dredge each piece thoroughly in seasoned flour.
Press coating firmly onto chicken.
Let coated chicken rest for 15 minutes.
Heat oil to 170°C (340°F) in a heavy pot or fryer.
Fry chicken in batches for 15-18 minutes, turning once.
Internal temperature should reach 74°C (165°F).
Drain on wire rack, season with salt immediately.
Rest 5 minutes before serving.
cooking_tips: Buttermilk tenderizes the meat and helps coating stick.
Don't crowd the fryer - it lowers oil temperature.
Cast iron gives the best results.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein. The buttermilk marinade adds calcium. Best enjoyed as an occasional treat due to frying.

short_description: Crispy chicken wings tossed in a tangy, spicy cayenne pepper sauce. Created in Buffalo, New York, these iconic wings are always served with cool blue cheese dressing and celery sticks.
steps: Pat wings completely dry with paper towels.
Heat oil to 190°C (375°F).
Fry wings in batches for 12-15 minutes until crispy.
Melt butter in a large bowl.
Add hot sauce and garlic powder to butter, whisk.
Toss crispy wings in the sauce.
Make blue cheese dressing by mixing crumbled cheese with sour cream and mayo.
Cut celery into sticks.
Serve wings hot with dressing and celery.
cooking_tips: Dry wings are essential for crispy skin.
Adjust hot sauce to your heat preference.
Traditional ratio is equal parts butter and hot sauce.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein. Hot sauce contains capsaicin with metabolic benefits. Blue cheese provides calcium.

short_description: Thinly sliced ribeye steak with melted cheese on a hoagie roll. Born in Philadelphia, this iconic sandwich features caramelized onions and the eternal debate: Cheez Whiz or provolone?
steps: Freeze steak for 30 minutes for easier slicing.
Slice steak paper-thin against the grain.
Slice onions and peppers thinly.
Heat oil on a griddle or large skillet.
Cook onions and peppers until caramelized.
Push vegetables aside, add meat in a single layer.
Season with salt and pepper.
Chop meat with spatula as it cooks.
Mix meat with vegetables, top with cheese.
Let cheese melt, then scoop into split rolls.
Serve immediately.
cooking_tips: Partially frozen meat slices thinner.
Use a flat griddle for authentic results.
Cheez Whiz is actually traditional!
nutrition_benefits: High in protein and iron from beef. Onions provide prebiotics. A hearty, filling meal.

short_description: The quintessential American creation - a juicy beef patty topped with melted cheese, fresh vegetables, and classic condiments on a soft bun. Simple perfection.
steps: Divide beef into 4 portions, form into patties slightly larger than buns.
Make a small indent in center of each patty.
Season generously with salt and pepper.
Heat a cast iron skillet or grill to high heat.
Cook patties 3-4 minutes per side for medium.
Add cheese in last minute of cooking, cover to melt.
Toast buns on the grill or in oven.
Apply condiments to buns.
Layer lettuce, tomato, patty, onion, and pickles.
Close burger and serve immediately.
cooking_tips: 80/20 beef ratio gives the juiciest burgers.
Don't press burgers while cooking - it releases juices.
The indent prevents puffing in the center.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein and iron. Tomatoes provide lycopene. A classic that satisfies.

short_description: Golden, slightly sweet cornbread baked in a cast iron skillet for a crispy crust. This Southern staple is the perfect accompaniment to chili, BBQ, or just slathered with butter.
steps: Preheat oven to 220°C (425°F).
Put butter in a 10-inch cast iron skillet, place in oven to melt.
Mix cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, soda, and salt.
Whisk buttermilk and eggs together.
Pour wet ingredients into dry, mix until just combined.
Carefully swirl melted butter in hot skillet.
Pour butter into batter, leaving some in skillet.
Pour batter into hot skillet.
Bake 20-25 minutes until golden and set.
Serve warm with butter and honey.
cooking_tips: The hot skillet creates the crispy crust.
Buttermilk can be substituted with milk plus lemon juice.
Southern style uses less sugar than Northern.
nutrition_benefits: Cornmeal provides fiber. Buttermilk adds calcium. A satisfying side dish.

short_description: Fluffy, buttery biscuits smothered in creamy sausage gravy. This hearty Southern breakfast is the ultimate comfort food, rich with savory pork sausage and cracked black pepper.
steps: For biscuits: mix flour, baking powder, and salt.
Cut in cold butter until pea-sized crumbs.
Add buttermilk and mix until just combined.
Pat dough to 1-inch thickness, cut into rounds.
Bake at 220°C (425°F) for 12-15 minutes until golden.
For gravy: brown sausage, breaking into crumbles.
Sprinkle 3 tbsp flour over sausage, cook 1 minute.
Gradually add milk, stirring constantly.
Simmer until thickened, season with pepper.
Split warm biscuits, ladle gravy over top.
cooking_tips: Cold butter is essential for flaky biscuits.
The gravy will thicken as it cools.
Use sage-flavored sausage for best results.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein from sausage. Provides sustained energy. A hearty meal for starting the day.

short_description: A spicy Cajun rice dish loaded with andouille sausage, shrimp, and chicken in a tomato-based sauce. This Louisiana classic brings the flavors of New Orleans to your table.
steps: Season chicken with cajun seasoning, brown in a large pot.
Remove chicken, add sliced sausage and brown.
Add the 'holy trinity': onion, celery, and bell pepper.
Cook until vegetables are soft.
Add tomatoes and remaining cajun seasoning.
Return chicken, add rice and broth.
Bring to boil, then reduce to simmer, cover.
Cook 20 minutes until rice is almost done.
Add shrimp, cook 5 more minutes until pink.
Let rest 5 minutes, then serve.
cooking_tips: Don't stir after adding rice - it causes sticking.
The 'holy trinity' is essential to Cajun cooking.
Adjust spice level to your preference.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein from three sources. Vegetables add fiber and vitamins. A complete, satisfying meal.

short_description: Slow-smoked pork shoulder shredded and dressed with tangy vinegar-based Carolina sauce. This BBQ classic is pile high on soft buns with creamy coleslaw.
steps: Mix brown sugar with paprika, garlic, onion, salt, and pepper for rub.
Coat pork shoulder generously with rub.
Smoke at 110°C (225°F) for 8-10 hours.
Or slow roast covered in oven at same temperature.
Meat is done when internal temp reaches 96°C (205°F).
Let rest 30 minutes.
Make sauce by mixing vinegar, ketchup, and hot sauce.
Shred meat using two forks.
Toss with enough sauce to moisten.
Serve on buns with coleslaw.
cooking_tips: Low and slow is the only way.
The fat cap helps keep meat moist.
Wrap in foil at 77°C (170°F) to push through the stall.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein. The slow cooking makes meat tender and easy to digest. A labor of love.

short_description: A tangy, creamy Florida classic made with tiny, aromatic Key limes in a graham cracker crust. Topped with billowy whipped cream, it's the perfect tropical dessert.
steps: Crush graham crackers finely.
Mix with melted butter.
Press into a 9-inch pie dish.
Bake crust at 180°C (350°F) for 10 minutes, cool.
Whisk egg yolks with condensed milk.
Add lime juice and zest, mix until thickened.
Pour into cooled crust.
Bake 15 minutes until set but slightly jiggly.
Cool completely, then chill for 4 hours.
Whip cream with sugar, spread on top.
cooking_tips: Real Key limes are essential for authentic flavor.
The filling sets from the acid, not just baking.
Must be served cold for best texture.
nutrition_benefits: Key limes provide vitamin C. Eggs add protein. A refreshing treat on hot days.

short_description: Creamy clam soup. Boston classic.
steps: Steam clams.
Cook potatoes.
Make cream base.
Combine all.
cooking_tips: Fresh clams.
Creamy texture.
Serve with crackers.
nutrition_benefits: Protein from clams.

short_description: Slow-smoked pork ribs. Southern BBQ.
steps: Apply rub.
Smoke low and slow.
Baste with sauce.
Serve tender.
cooking_tips: Low temperature.
Wood smoke.
Fall off bone.
nutrition_benefits: High protein.

short_description: Lobster salad in buttered bun. Maine specialty.
steps: Cook lobster.
Chop meat.
Mix with mayo.
Serve in toasted bun.
cooking_tips: Fresh lobster.
Light on mayo.
Butter the bun.
nutrition_benefits: Lean protein.

short_description: Cajun stew with okra. Louisiana classic.
steps: Make dark roux.
Add holy trinity.
Add proteins.
Simmer long.
cooking_tips: Dark roux essential.
File powder optional.
Serve over rice.
nutrition_benefits: Flavorful stew.

short_description: Classic American dessert. As American as...
steps: Slice apples.
Make filling.
Line pie dish.
Bake until golden.
cooking_tips: Mix apple varieties.
Warm is best.
Serve with ice cream.
nutrition_benefits: Classic comfort.

short_description: Creamy cheese pasta. Ultimate comfort.
steps: Cook pasta.
Make cheese sauce.
Combine.
Bake until bubbly.
cooking_tips: Sharp cheddar.
Creamy sauce.
Breadcrumb topping.
nutrition_benefits: Calcium from cheese.

steps: Steam clams.
Cook potatoes.
Make cream base.
Combine all.
cooking_tips: Fresh clams.
Creamy texture.
Serve with crackers.

Baste with sauce.
Serve tender.
cooking_tips: Low temperature.

Fall off bone.

Serve in toasted bun.
cooking_tips: Fresh lobster.

Butter the bun.
